subject: Chemistry

figures.description: Set of curves labeled P, Q, R, S with temperature marks along the x-axis (e.g., 298 K, 323 K, 353 K). Used in Question 7 to identify the P–V relationship for an ideal gas at constant temperature.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: The average kinetic enemy of a gas is directly proportional to its temperature
At constant temperature, the volume of a gas increases as the pressure increases.
The pressure of a gas is inversely proportional to its volume.
The temperature of gas is directly proportional to its volume.

questions.explanation: For an ideal gas, average kinetic energy is proportional to absolute temperature. Option B is opposite of Boyle’s law, C is Boyle’s law but the question asks for the best correct statement and A is also correct; however C is also correct at constant temperature. Since the stem allows one best answer, A is the standard kinetic theory statement explicitly about average kinetic energy.

questions.question: Which are the correct IUPAC names for H–CO₂CH₃ and CH≡CH
questions.explanation: H–CO₂CH₃ is the methyl ester of methanoic acid → methyl methanoate. CH≡CH is ethyne.

questions.question: A solution X on mixing with AgNO₃ solution, gives a white precipitate soluble in NH₃(aq). A solution Y, when added to X also gives a white precipitate which is soluble on boiling. Solution Y contains
questions.explanation: White precipitate with AgNO₃ soluble in NH₃ indicates Cl⁻ (AgCl dissolves in NH₃). A white precipitate soluble on boiling is characteristic of PbCl₂ (soluble in hot water). Therefore Y supplies Pb²⁺.

questions.question: Methane is a member of the homologous series called
questions.explanation: Methane (CH₄) is a saturated hydrocarbon; saturated hydrocarbons are alkanes.

questions.question: Which of the following bonds exists in crystalline ammonium chloride (NH₄Cl)?
questions.explanation: NH₄Cl has ionic attraction between NH₄⁺ and Cl⁻. Within NH₄⁺, N–H bonds are covalent, with one formed by donation of N’s lone pair to H⁺ (coordinate/dative).

questions.question: Some copper (II) sulphate pentahydrate (CuSO₄·5H₂O), was heated at 120°C with the following results: Wt of crucible = 10.00 g; Wt of crucible + CuSO₄·5H₂O = 14.98 g; Wt of crucible + residue = 13.54 g. How many molecules of water of crystallization were lost? [H = 1, Cu = 63.5, O = 16, S = 32]
questions.explanation: Mass of hydrated salt = 14.98 − 10.00 = 4.98 g. Mass of residue = 13.54 − 10.00 = 3.54 g. Water lost = 4.98 − 3.54 = 1.44 g. Moles H₂O lost = 1.44/18 = 0.08 mol. Moles CuSO₄ in residue: molar mass CuSO₄ = 63.5 + 32 + 4×16 = 159.5 g mol⁻¹; moles = 3.54/159.5 ≈ 0.0222 mol. Water per CuSO₄ lost = 0.08/0.0222 ≈ 3.6 ≈ 4, but the closest valid dehydration step from CuSO₄·5H₂O at 120°C is typically to CuSO₄·2H₂O (loss of 3 waters). Using the measured data, expected integer is 3 as the best match among options.

questions.question: Which of the curves shown above represents the relationships between the volume (v) and pressure (p) of an ideal gas at constant temperature?
questions.explanation: The figure is present but the axes labels and which variable is plotted against which are not clearly readable in the provided crop, and the curves P, Q, R, S are not unambiguously identified as P–V isotherms. From the image alone, the correct curve cannot be extracted with high confidence.

questions.question: 12.0 g of a mixture of potassium carbonate and potassium chloride were dissolved in a 250 cm³ standard flask. 25 cm³ of this solution required 40.00 cm³ of 0.1 M HCl neutralization. What is the percentage by weight of K₂CO₃ in the mixture (K = 39, O = 16, C = 12)
questions.explanation: Reaction: \(\text{K}_2\text{CO}_3 + 2\text{HCl} \rightarrow 2\text{KCl} + \text{H}_2\text{O} + \text{CO}_2\). Moles HCl in 40.00 cm³ of 0.1 M = 0.1×(40/1000)=0.004 mol. Moles K₂CO₃ in 25 cm³ aliquot = 0.004/2=0.002 mol. In 250 cm³ (10× aliquot): moles = 0.002×10=0.020 mol. Molar mass K₂CO₃ = 2(39)+12+3(16)=78+12+48=138 g/mol. Mass K₂CO₃ = 0.020×138=2.76 g. Percentage in 12.0 g mixture = (2.76/12.0)×100 = 23%. This does not match any option; therefore some value in the question as shown (either volume, molarity, or total mass) is likely missing/misread from the image.

questions.question: Which of the following, groups of physical properties increases from left to right of the Periodic Table? 1. Ionization energy 2. Atomic radius 3. Electronegativity 4. Electron affinity
questions.explanation: Across a period, electronegativity and electron affinity generally increase, while atomic radius decreases. The only option excluding atomic radius is C.

questions.question: An element Z contained 90% of \(^{8}\text{Z}^{16}\) and 10% of \(^{8}\text{Z}^{18}\). Its relative atomic mass is
What are the possible oxidation numbers for an element if its atomic number is 17?
questions.explanation: Atomic number 17 is chlorine. It commonly shows -1 and positive oxidation states up to +7.

questions.question: How many valence electrons are contained in the element represented by \(^{31}_{15}\text{P}\)?
questions.explanation: Phosphorus (Z=15) is in Group 15, with 5 valence electrons.

questions.question: 10.0 dm³ of air containing H₂S as an impurity was passed through a solution of Pb(NO₃)₂ until all the H₂S had reacted. The precipitate of PbS was found to weigh 5.02 g. According to the equation: Pb(NO₃)₂ + H₂S → PbS + 2HNO₃ the percentage by volume of hydrogen sulphide in the air is
questions.explanation: Molar mass PbS = 207 + 32 = 239 g/mol. Moles PbS = 5.02/239 = 0.0210 mol. Stoichiometry 1:1 gives moles H₂S = 0.0210 mol. At the same conditions, gas volume \(V = n\times 22.4\,\text{dm}^3\) (assuming STP) gives \(0.0210\times 22.4 = 0.470\,\text{dm}^3\). Percentage in 10.0 dm³ = (0.470/10.0)×100 = 4.70%.

questions.question: A quantity of air was passed through a weighed amount of alkaline pyrogallol. An increase in the weight of the pyrogallol would result from the absorption of
questions.explanation: Alkaline pyrogallol absorbs oxygen from air, increasing its mass.

questions.question: Water for town supply is chlorinated to make it free from
questions.explanation: Chlorination disinfects water by killing disease-causing microorganisms.

questions.question: 4.0 g of sodium hydroxide in 250 cm³ of solution contains
questions.explanation: Molar mass NaOH = 40 g/mol. Moles = 4.0/40 = 0.10 mol. Volume = 250 cm³ = 0.25 dm³. Concentration = 0.10/0.25 = 0.40 mol dm⁻³, which corresponds to option A, not B.

questions.question: A major effect of oil pollution in coastal waters is the

options.text: increase in the acidity of the water

questions.explanation: Oil films reduce oxygen transfer and harm organisms (smothering, токсicity), leading to destruction of marine life.

questions.question: In general, an increase in temperature increases the solubility of a solute in water because

options.text: more solute molecules collide with each other
most solutes dissolve with the evolution of heat
more solute molecules dissociate at higher temperatures
most solutes dissolve with absorption of heat.

questions.explanation: Many solid solutes dissolve endothermically; increasing temperature favors dissolution (Le Châtelier), increasing solubility.

questions.question: The relatively high boiling points of alkanols are due to
questions.explanation: Alcohols form intermolecular hydrogen bonds via the O–H group, raising boiling points.

questions.question: Given that 15.00 cm³ of H₂SO₄ was required to completely neutralize 25.00 cm³ of 0.125 mol dm³ NaOH, calculate the molar concentration of the acid solution
questions.explanation: Equation: \(\text{H}_2\text{SO}_4 + 2\text{NaOH} \rightarrow \text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4 + 2\text{H}_2\text{O}\). Moles NaOH = 0.125×(25/1000)=0.003125 mol. Moles H₂SO₄ = 0.003125/2=0.0015625 mol. Volume acid = 15/1000 = 0.015 dm³. Concentration = 0.0015625/0.015 = 0.1042 mol dm⁻³ → option C, not B.

questions.question: What volume of 0.1 mol dm³ solution of tetraoxosulphate (VI) acid would be needed to dissolve 2.86 g of sodium trioxocarbonate (IV) decahydrate crystals? [H = 1, C = 12, O = 16, S = 32, Na = 23].
questions.explanation: Na₂CO₃·10H₂O molar mass = (2×23)+12+(3×16)+10×18 = 46+12+48+180=286 g/mol. Moles = 2.86/286 = 0.010 mol. Reaction with H₂SO₄: Na₂CO₃ + H₂SO₄ → Na₂SO₄ + CO₂ + H₂O (1:1). Moles acid needed = 0.010 mol. Volume of 0.1 M acid = n/C = 0.010/0.1 = 0.10 dm³ = 100 cm³ → option D, not C.

questions.question: The solution with the lowest pH value is
questions.explanation: Lowest pH corresponds to highest \([\text{H}^+]\). Concentrations: M/10 = 0.1 M; M/5 = 0.2 M; M/8 = 0.125 M. The highest concentration listed is M/5 (0.2 M), so it gives the lowest pH regardless of volume.

questions.question: In which order are the following salts sensitive to light?
questions.explanation: Silver bromide is most photosensitive (used in photographic films), followed by AgCl, then AgI.

questions.question: A metal m displaces Zinc from Zinc chloride solution. This shows that

options.text: M is more electronegative than Zinc
Zinc is above hydrogen in the series.
M is more electropositive than zinc.
electrons flow from zinc to m.

questions.explanation: Displacement means M is more reactive (more readily oxidized) than Zn, i.e., more electropositive.

questions.question: Steam changes the colour of anhydrous cobalt (II) chloride from
questions.explanation: Anhydrous CoCl₂ is blue; hydration by steam forms pink hydrated CoCl₂.

questions.question: When at equilibrium, which of the reactions below will shift to the right if the pressure is increased and the temperature is kept constant?
questions.explanation: Increasing pressure favors the side with fewer moles of gas. Only option C goes from 3 moles (left) to 2 moles (right), so it shifts right.

questions.question: 2CO(g) + O2(g) → 2CO2(g). Given that \(\Delta H_f^\circ(\text{CO}) = -110.4\,\text{kJ mol}^{-1}\) and \(\Delta H_f^\circ(\text{CO}_2) = -393.0\,\text{kJ mol}^{-1}\), the energy change for the reaction above is
questions.explanation: \(\Delta H = \sum \Delta H_f^\circ(\text{products}) - \sum \Delta H_f^\circ(\text{reactants})\). Products: 2(−393.0)=−786.0. Reactants: 2(−110.4)+0=−220.8. \(\Delta H = -786.0 - (-220.8) = -565.2\,\text{kJ}\). This value is not in the options; using the values as printed in the image, the closest negative large magnitude is option A (−503.7 kJ), but it does not match the calculation exactly.

questions.question: Which of these properties gives a solid its definite shape?
questions.explanation: Solids have particles held closely in fixed positions by strong intermolecular forces, giving a definite shape.

questions.question: When a crystal was added to the clear solution of its salt, the crystal did not dissolve and the solution remained unchanged. This showed that the solution was
questions.explanation: In a saturated solution, added solute does not dissolve (at that temperature) and the solution remains unchanged.

questions.question: If the electron configuration of an element is \(1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^5\), how many unpaired electrons are there?
questions.explanation: For \(2p^5\), the three p orbitals fill singly first, then pair: distribution leaves one unpaired electron.

questions.question: The substance that is used in the steel industry for the removal of carbon, sulphur and phosphorus impurities from pig iron is
questions.explanation: Oxygen is blown through molten pig iron to oxidize impurities (C to CO/CO2, S and P to oxides) during steelmaking.

questions.question: Hydrogen sulphide gas can act as
questions.explanation: H2S precipitates many metal ions as insoluble metal sulphides (e.g., PbS, CuS), so it acts as a precipitating agent in qualitative analysis.

questions.question: Which of the following is used as a rocket fuel?
questions.explanation: Nitric acid has been used as an oxidizer component in some rocket propellants.

questions.question: The bleaching action of chlorine is effective due to the presence of
questions.explanation: Chlorine bleaches in moist conditions by forming HOCl in water, which acts as an oxidizing agent.

questions.question: Mineral acids are usually added to commercial hydrogen peroxide to

options.text: reduce it to water and oxygen.

questions.explanation: Small amounts of acid stabilize H2O2, slowing down its decomposition.

questions.question: Aluminium containers are frequently used to transport trioxonitrate (V) acid because aluminium

options.text: does not react with the acid

questions.explanation: Concentrated nitric acid passivates aluminium by forming a protective oxide layer, so it effectively does not continue reacting.

questions.question: Ethyne is passed through a hot tube containing organo-nickel catalyst to produce
questions.explanation: Ethyne can cyclotrimerize under catalytic conditions: \(3\text{C}_2\text{H}_2 \rightarrow \text{C}_6\text{H}_6\) (benzene).

questions.question: The process of converting starch to ethanol is
questions.explanation: Starch is converted to sugars and then fermented by yeast to produce ethanol.

questions.question: An endothermic reaction is one during which heat is ____ and can be represented by the symbol ____. Which of the combinations can be used accurately to complete the above definition?
questions.explanation: Endothermic reactions absorb heat and have positive enthalpy change (\(\Delta H > 0\)).

questions.question: Consider the following exothermic reaction \(2\text{SO}_2(g) + \text{O}_2(g) \rightleftharpoons 2\text{SO}_3(g)\). If the temperature of the reaction is reduced from 800°C to 500°C, and no other change takes place, then
questions.explanation: This question is incomplete in the provided images: only option A is partially visible and the remaining options (and full statement) are not shown, so the correct answer cannot be determined from the uploads.

missingQuestions: Question 40 options B, C, D (and any continuation of option A) are cut off in the provided images.
Questions 41–50 are not present in the uploaded images.
